quoteFirst: Sydney looked at his watch; it was a
quoteLast: . The last train left for London soon after eight. The station was nearly eight miles off; the dog-cart in which he had come was waiting at the door; he had not much time to spare if the train was not to go without him.

quoteFirst: Would you like a final example?  Observe your husband.  Yesterday he went out in a bad temper--he had breakfasted badly--and lo! in the evening, at a
quoteLast: , he came home from the Chamber joyful and well- pleased, a smile on his lips, and good-humor in his eye.  He kissed you on the forehead with a certain unconstraint, threw a number of pamphlets and papers with an easy gesture on the sidetable, sat down to table, found the soup delicious, and ate joyously.
title: Monsieur, Madame, and Bébé — Volume 03
author: Droz, Gustave, 1832-1895

quoteFirst: Madame Carson was not at home all this while. She had gone to church, and after devotions, called on her way back on one or two friends for a little gossip, so that it wanted only about a
quoteLast: when she reappeared. Of course the lamentable story had to be told over again, with all its dismal accompaniments of tears, sighs, and plaintive ejaculations; and it was curious to observe, as the narrative proceeded, how the widow's charming eyes flashed and sparkled, and her cheeks glowed with indignation, till she looked, to use Edouard le Blanc's expression, 'ferociously' handsome.
title:
Chambers's Edinburgh Journal, No. 447
Volume 18, New Series, July 24, 1852
author: Various; Chambers, Robert, 1802-1871 [Editor]; Chambers, William, 1800-1883 [Editor]

quoteFirst: The crew practised three mornings a week before breakfast. Katherine, who had gone to sleep with the idea firmly fixed in her mind that she must wake by a
quoteLast: so that she could rouse the others, awoke with a start, dreaming that she had overslept and the others had tied her in her bed and gone off without her. The world was dull and grey and covered with a chilly mist. There was nothing to inspire a desire to go war canoe practicing.
title: The Camp Fire Girls on Ellen's Isle; Or, The Trail of the Seven Cedars

quoteFirst: "Rose at
quoteLast: .  Stopped at six wood yards trying to get wood in exchange for printing, but failed.  Did very little in office. Walked and talked with Ike.  Felt very blue and thought of drawing out. Saw Dr. Eaton, but failed to make a trade.  In evening saw Dr. Morse. Have not done all, nor as well as I could wish.  Also wrote to Boyne, but did not mail letter.
title: Stories of Achievement, Volume IV, Authors and Journalists
author: Dickinson, Asa Don, 1876-1960 [Editor]
